newsitem.title: USA: US high-yield bonds queasy on Treas, stock selling.
newsitem.headline: US high-yield bonds queasy on Treas, stock selling.

text.p: Deep losses in the U.S. Treasury and stock markets on Thursday nurtured a queasy tone in the high-yield bond market, while issuers injected several large new issues, dealers said.

Telecommunication deals, including $300 million in two-tranches from WinStar Communications Inc and $200 million from Ionica Plc, were forced to either jack-up yields or add contingent warrants to entice investors, sources said.
Investment grade issuance approached the $1 billion mark, meanwhile, as issuers moved to capture Treasury yields while they were still below seven percent, dealers said.
Secondary corporate spreads were somewhat tighter on the whole, they added, with accounts opting for the sidelines as Treasuries reacted to anticipated higher interest rates.

The benchmark 30-year bond dropped nearly one point following a jump in retail sales data and hawkish comments from Chicago Federal Reserve Bank President Michael Moskow. The Dow Jones Industrial Average, meanwhile, fell 160 points.

Back in high-yields, WinStar (rated CCC-plus) sold $100 million 14.5 percent eight-year senior deferred interest notes at par, while WinStar Equipment set $200 million 12.5 percent seven-year guaranteed senior secured notes, also at par.
Yield talk on both tranches was increased on Wednesday. A separate $150 million senior subordinated deferred interest notes was chopped off the deal on Wednesday.
Bids for WinStar's new notes fell to 99-1/2 by mid-session, traders said.

Ionica's $200 million 15 percent 10-year senior discount note offering apparently won more favor in the secondary market, but not before the addition of contingent warrants for five percent of the company.
The issue gained about one point to a 48-1/4 bid, 48-3/4 offer market near the close from an issued price of 47.688.

George Edwards, portfolio manager with Prudential Investments, said secondary activity was a a minimum on Thursday, but expected the weakness to translate to wider spreads on tightly priced paper in the near term.

"An awful lot of new deals away from communications have been priced tightly and those will probably trade down to a discount just because there isn't a lot of give in that spread and they'll almost have to track Treasuries," Edwards said, adding that price movements may be 1/4 to 1/2 point.
In other new issuance, Booth Creek Ski Holdings Inc issued $110 million 12.5 percent 10-year senior notes at par.
Quality Food Centers Inc increased its 10-year senior subordinated note deal to $150 million from $125 million and priced the debt at par to yield 200 basis points over.

High-yield secondary names were 1/4 to 3/8 point lower on a broad basis amid unenthusiastic activity, traders and managers said. Traders said the day was marked with low bids with no offerings or "less serious" bids out to test waters.
Reflecting that sentiment, Brooks Fiber Properties Inc's zero coupon bonds were seen at 66-1/4 bid compared with Wednesday's bid level of 67.
Investment grade prices were socked with Treasuries but traders cuffed spreads two to three basis points tighter on average. Still, activity was dull with focus on new issues.

From Northwest Airlines Inc, dealers priced $150 million seven- and 10-year notes as 8-3/8s to yield 175 basis points off the curve and another $100 million 10-year notes as 8.70s to yield 200 basis points over.
Northwest is a Ba2/BB-minus crossover name, traders said.

Elsewhere, Archer Daniels Midland Co issued $350 million 7-1/2 percent 30-year bonds to yield 55 basis points over and Fifth Third Capital Trust I sold $200 million 8.136 percent 30-year capital securities to yield 110 basis points over.
